issues.text: Whether the orders and acts of dispossession by the State and its officers amount to a flagrant violation of the petitioners' fundamental rights under Articles 14, 19 and 31 of the Constitution by depriving them of property without authority of law

issues.text: Whether the petitioners were mere trespassers in respect of the dharmasala, temple and shops such that the State was entitled to eject them using minimum force

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the respondents has sought to justify that action on the ground that the petitioners were mere trespassers and as the land on which the dharmasala stood belonged to the State, the respondents were entitled to use the minimum of force to eject the trespassers.

holdings.text: We consider that both these contentions are unsound and the petitioners have made out a clear case of the violation of their fundamental rights.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent contentions of trespass and factual disputes rejected on admitted facts of permission-based possession and executive dispossession without legal process.

holdings.text: On this admitted position the petitioners cannot be held to be trespassers in respect of the dharmasala, temple and shops nor can it be held that the dharmasala, temple and shops belonged to the State, irrespective of the question whether the trust created was of a public or private nature.
holdings.reasoning_summary: State permission granted for construction and continuous management by petitioners and predecessor establish bona fide possession, not trespass.

holdings.text: A trustee even of a public trust can be removed only by procedure known to law. He cannot be removed by an executive fiat.

anchor.surface_text: A trustee even of a public trust can be removed only by procedure known to law. He cannot be removed by an executive fiat.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming public charitable trust, executive lacks authority to dispossess trustee without due legal process.

holdings.text: It is by now well settled that the maxim, what is annexed to the soil goes with the soil, has not been accepted as an absolute rule of law of this country.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents establish maxim not absolute where constructions made with permission on another's land.

holdings.text: These decisions show that a person who bona fide puts up constructions on land belonging to others with their permission would not be a trespasser, nor would the buildings so constructed vest in the owner of the land by the application of the maxim quicquid plantatur solo, solo cedit.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of cited precedents to facts of permission and bona fide construction.

holdings.text: It is well recognised that a suit under s. 92, Civil Procedure Code, may be brought against persons in possession of the trust property even if they claim adversely to the trust, that is, claim to be owners of the property, or against persons who deny the validity of the trust.

anchor.surface_text: It is well recognised that a suit under s. 92, Civil Procedure Code, may be brought against persons in possession of the trust property even if they claim adversely to the trust, that is, claim to be owners of the property, or against persons who deny the validity of the trust.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provision applies regardless of adverse claims, mandating judicial process for removal.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary in this case to determine any disputed questions of fact or even to determine what precise right the petitioners obtained by the sanction granted to their firm in 1909. It is enough to say that they are bona fide in possession of the constructions in question and could not be removed except under authority of law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 32 jurisdiction protects bona fide possession from executive interference without resolving title disputes.

holdings.text: The respondents clearly violated their fundamental rights by depriving them of possession of the dharmasala by executive orders. Those orders must be quashed and the respondents must be restrained from interfering with the petitioners in the management of the dharmasala, temple and shops. A writ will issue accordingly.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct consequence of prior holdings on possession and lack of legal authority.

holdings.text: Before we part with this case, we feel it our duty to say that the executive action taken in this case by the State and its officers is destructive of the basic principle of the rule of law.

anchor.surface_text: Before we part with this case, we feel it our duty to say that the executive action taken in this case by the State and its officers is destructive of the basic principle of the rule of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executive dispossession without judicial process undermines constitutional rule of law.

holdings.text: the facts and the position in law thus clearly are 1 that the buildings constructed on this piece of Government land did not belong to Government, 2 that the petitioners were in possession and occupation of the buildings and 3 that by virtue of enactments binding on the Government, the petitioners could be dispossessed, if at all, only in pursuance of a decree of a Civil Court obtained in proceedings properly initiated.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Summarizes key legal and factual determinations justifying relief.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by this Court in Wazir Chand v. The State of Himachal Pradesh  1 , the State or its executive officers cannot in- terfere with the rights of others unless they can point to some specific rule of law which authorises their acts.
